articles.headline: As Donald Trump Repels Minority Voters, G.O.P. Fears Its Future in the West
articles.snippet: Republicans are concerned that Mr. Trump is accelerating the broader population shifts that threaten the party’s standing in Western states.
articles.abstract: Republicans are concerned that Mr. Trump is accelerating the broader population shifts that threaten the party’s standing in Western states.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Republicans in Western states fear that Donald J. Trump could imperil their party for years to come in the country’s fastest-growing region as he repels a generation of Hispanics, Asians and younger voters who have been altering the electoral map.

articles.headline: Breitbart Rises From Outlier to Potent Voice in Campaign
articles.snippet: The renegade opinion and news site, once a curiosity of the fringe right wing, is now an increasingly powerful voice for millions of disaffected conservatives.
articles.abstract: The renegade opinion and news site, once a curiosity of the fringe right wing, is now an increasingly powerful voice for millions of disaffected conservatives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Breitbart News has arrived.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and John Herrman

articles.headline: University of Chicago Strikes Back Against Campus Political Correctness
articles.snippet: A letter to incoming freshmen professed no support for “trigger warnings” or limits on what kinds of speech should be condoned on campus.
articles.abstract: A letter to incoming freshmen professed no support for “trigger warnings” or limits on what kinds of speech should be condoned on campus.
articles.lead_paragraph: The anodyne welcome letter to incoming freshmen is a college staple, but this week the University of Chicago took a different approach: It sent new students a blunt statement opposing some hallmarks of campus political correctness, drawing thousands of impassioned responses, for and against, as it caromed around cyberspace.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña, Mitch Smith and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: G.E., the 124-Year-Old Software Start-Up
articles.snippet: The industrial giant is investing big in an effort to adopt the nimble habits and digital wizardry of Silicon Valley. And, its C.E.O. says, there is no Plan B.
articles.abstract: The industrial giant is investing big in an effort to adopt the nimble habits and digital wizardry of Silicon Valley. And, its C.E.O. says, there is no Plan B.
articles.lead_paragraph: It may not qualify as a lightning-bolt eureka moment, but Jeffrey R. Immelt, chief executive of General Electric, recalls the June day in 2009 that got him thinking. He was speaking with G.E. scientists about new jet engines they were building, laden with sensors to generate a trove of data from every flight — but to what end?

articles.headline: SEAL Team 6 and a Man Left for Dead: A Grainy Picture of Valor
articles.snippet: An airman with the unit is being considered for the Medal of Honor after new video analysis suggested that he fought alone bravely in a 2002 battle on an Afghan peak.
articles.abstract: An airman with the unit is being considered for the Medal of Honor after new video analysis suggested that he fought alone bravely in a 2002 battle on an Afghan peak.
articles.lead_paragraph: Britt Slabinski could hear the bullets ricochet off the rocks in the darkness. It was the first firefight for his six-man reconnaissance unit from SEAL Team 6, and it was outnumbered, outgunned and taking casualties on an Afghan mountaintop.
articles.byline: By Sean D. Naylor and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: Packing Technology Into the Timeless Barrel
articles.snippet: American barrel-making is on the upswing, fed by demand from winemakers, distillers and brewers, and science is transforming the ancient craft.
articles.abstract: American barrel-making is on the upswing, fed by demand from winemakers, distillers and brewers, and science is transforming the ancient craft.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALEM, Mo. — Standing on a wooded hillside in the Ozarks, about 100 miles southwest of St. Louis, Brad Boswell watches a chain-saw-wielding logger make several deft cuts at the base of a 100-foot white oak. The logger points to a clearing down the slope and, with one final, quick slash, sends the tree falling, exactly where he pointed.

articles.headline: ‘No Vacancies’ for Blacks: How Donald Trump Got His Start, and Was First Accused of Bias
articles.snippet: As Mr. Trump assumed an increasing role in his father’s business, the company’s practice of turning away potential black tenants was painstakingly documented.
articles.abstract: As Mr. Trump assumed an increasing role in his father’s business, the company’s practice of turning away potential black tenants was painstakingly documented.
articles.lead_paragraph: She seemed like the model tenant. A 33-year-old nurse who was living at the Y.W.C.A. in Harlem, she had come to rent a one-bedroom at the still-unfinished Wilshire Apartments in the Jamaica Estates neighborhood of Queens. She filled out what the rental agent remembers as a “beautiful application.” She did not even want to look at the unit.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Mahler and Steve Eder

articles.headline: A Powerful Russian Weapon: The Spread of False Stories
articles.snippet: Using both conventional media and covert channels, the Kremlin relies on disinformation to create doubt, fear and discord in Europe and the United States.
articles.abstract: Using both conventional media and covert channels, the Kremlin relies on disinformation to create doubt, fear and discord in Europe and the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: STOCKHOLM — With a vigorous national debate underway on whether Sweden should enter a military partnership with NATO, officials in Stockholm suddenly encountered an unsettling problem: a flood of distorted and outright false information on social media, confusing public perceptions of the issue.

articles.headline: Democrats Step Up Pursuit of House Republicans Left Limping by Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s unpopularity with voters in affluent, suburban areas has jeopardized several Republican incumbents, opening the chance for Democrats to win in conservative districts.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s unpopularity with voters in affluent, suburban areas has jeopardized several Republican incumbents, opening the chance for Democrats to win in conservative districts.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEESBURG, Va. — Emboldened by Donald J. Trump’s struggles in the presidential race, Democrats in Congress are laying the groundwork to expand the list of House Republicans they will target for defeat as part of an effort to slash the Republicans’ 30-seat majority and even reclaim control if Mr. Trump falls further.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Crackdown on For-Profit Colleges May Free Students and Trap Taxpayers
articles.snippet: The goal of relieving students saddled with onerous debt and a subpar education can be at odds with reducing the cost to taxpayers who are likely to be stuck with the bill.
articles.abstract: The goal of relieving students saddled with onerous debt and a subpar education can be at odds with reducing the cost to taxpayers who are likely to be stuck with the bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s decision to bar ITT Educational Services, one of the nation’s largest operators of for-profit colleges, from using federal financial aid to enroll new students shuts off the cash spigot to the troubled company. But it also creates a new set of problems.

articles.headline: Plane Rides and Presidential Transparency
articles.snippet: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump have not allowed the press corps to travel with them on their campaign airplanes, suspending a tradition that had lasted more than 50 years.
articles.abstract: Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump have not allowed the press corps to travel with them on their campaign airplanes, suspending a tradition that had lasted more than 50 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton headed for Reno, Nev., to make a big speech attacking Donald J. Trump on Thursday, her campaign used two planes. One was for the candidate and her entourage. The other was for the reporters, photographers and videographers assigned to follow her every move — which, of course, is impossible when she’s not physically on the same aircraft.

articles.headline: An Epidemic of ‘Dead Eyes’ in Kashmir as India Uses Pellet Guns on Protesters
articles.snippet: The nonlethal weapon employed by Indian security forces to disperse crowds since early July can cause ghastly damage, often blinding victims, some of them children.
articles.abstract: The nonlethal weapon employed by Indian security forces to disperse crowds since early July can cause ghastly damage, often blinding victims, some of them children.
articles.lead_paragraph: SRINAGAR, Kashmir — The street outside is patrolled by riot police officers in camouflage, bracing for the nightly spasm of violence, but it is quiet here inside the operating room. The surgeon’s knife slides into an eyeball as if it were a soft fruit.

articles.headline: Central Bankers Hear Plea: Turn Focus to Government Spending
articles.snippet: At an annual conference of central bankers, experts said that increased government spending, not just low rates, was needed to spur growth.
articles.abstract: At an annual conference of central bankers, experts said that increased government spending, not just low rates, was needed to spur growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK, Wyo. — Central bankers who gathered here to discuss better ways of jump-starting slow economic growth received a surprising message from their lunchtime speaker on Friday: Stop. You’re making things worse.

articles.headline: Warned of a Crash, Start-Ups in Silicon Valley Narrow Their Focus
articles.snippet: Start-ups were to face a great reckoning in 2016. The crash hasn’t happened, but companies are making some adjustments.
articles.abstract: Start-ups were to face a great reckoning in 2016. The crash hasn’t happened, but companies are making some adjustments.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Evernote, a Silicon Valley start-up that makes a note-taking app, was supposed to be dead by now.

articles.headline: Coal Country Is Wary of Hillary Clinton’s Pledge to Help
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton is promising $30 billion to create a new economy by retraining miners and investing in technology, but locals have heard promises before.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton is promising $30 billion to create a new economy by retraining miners and investing in technology, but locals have heard promises before.
articles.lead_paragraph: LEBANON, Va. — As Kevin Widener was growing up on his family’s tobacco farm in the rolling hills of southwest Virginia in the 1990s, lawmakers and lawyers in Washington were waging a war on smoking.

articles.headline: Broadband Law Could Force Rural Residents Off Information Superhighway
articles.snippet: A federal court ruling may halt the spread of municipal high-speed internet providers, which often serve households and businesses where commercial cable and telecom firms have been unwilling to go.
articles.abstract: A federal court ruling may halt the spread of municipal high-speed internet providers, which often serve households and businesses where commercial cable and telecom firms have been unwilling to go.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILSON, N.C. — On the first day of the harvest last week, a line of trucks brimming with sweet potatoes rolled into Vick Family Farms, headed for a new packing plant that runs on ultrafast internet.

articles.headline: Mylan Tries Again to Quell Pricing Outrage by Offering Generic EpiPen
articles.snippet: Critics are still not mollified after the pharmaceutical maker introduced a generic competitor to its own branded product, EpiPen, at half the price.
articles.abstract: Critics are still not mollified after the pharmaceutical maker introduced a generic competitor to its own branded product, EpiPen, at half the price.
articles.lead_paragraph: In its latest move to quell outrage over its price increases, the maker of the EpiPen has resorted to an unusual tactic — introducing a generic version of its own product.

articles.headline: Obamacare Marketplaces Are in Trouble. What Can Be Done?
articles.snippet: A look at four major challenges the Affordable Care Act is facing, and some possible solutions.
articles.abstract: A look at four major challenges the Affordable Care Act is facing, and some possible solutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been a hard couple of weeks for Obamacare. The law’s online marketplaces — where people were supposed to be able to easily shop for health insurance — have been suffering from high-profile defections and double-digit premium increases.
articles.byline: By Reed Abelson and Margot Sanger-Katz

articles.headline: Once a Qaeda Recruiter, Now a Voice Against Jihad
articles.snippet: In a new effort to counter the lure of terrorism, a former American jihadist is moving into the public sphere to research the ideology he once spread.
articles.abstract: In a new effort to counter the lure of terrorism, a former American jihadist is moving into the public sphere to research the ideology he once spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the four years that he ran the Revolution Muslim website out of his walk-up apartment in Flatbush, Brooklyn, Jesse Morton became one of the most prolific recruiters for Al Qaeda, luring numerous Americans to the group’s violent ideology.

articles.headline: Anthony Weiner and Huma Abedin to Separate After His Latest Sexting Scandal
articles.snippet: The former congressman was said to have exchanged sexual messages with a woman last year, four years after a similar scandal cost him his political career.
articles.abstract: The former congressman was said to have exchanged sexual messages with a woman last year, four years after a similar scandal cost him his political career.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a quiet, late-summer weekend on the exclusive shores of the Hamptons. But on Sunday, Huma Abedin, the closest aide to Hillary Clinton, received devastating news.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Back-to-School Divide: $195 Headbands and $1 Glue Sticks
articles.snippet: As the income gap in the United States has widened, luxury and discount retailers have become increasingly deft at drawing people at separate ends of the income spectrum.
articles.abstract: As the income gap in the United States has widened, luxury and discount retailers have become increasingly deft at drawing people at separate ends of the income spectrum.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fashion brand Kate Spade is most known for luxury handbags. But it is also banking on gold-accented staplers, monogrammed planners and $30 ballpoint pens to help buoy sales during the increasingly important back-to-school shopping season.
